body.default: {{ body }}<hr>This is an automatic backport of pull request #{{number}} done by [Mergify](https://mergify.com).
body.title: Body

message.default: This pull request has been automatically closed by Mergify.
message.title: Message

message.description: The message to write as a comment.
message.title: Message

bot_account.description: Mergify can impersonate a GitHub user to comment a pull request. If no `bot_account` is set, Mergify will comment the pull request itself.
bot_account.title: Bot Account

body.default: {{ body }}<hr>This is an automatic copy of pull request #{{number}} done by [Mergify](https://mergify.com).
body.title: Body

force.description: If set to `true`, the branch will be deleted even if another pull request depends on the head branch. GitHub will therefore close the dependent pull requests.
force.title: Force

approved.description: If set to `true`, all the approving reviews will be removed when the pull request is updated. If set to `false`, nothing will be done. If set to a list, each item should be the GitHub login of a user whose review will be removed. If set to `from_requested_reviewers`, the list of requested reviewers will be used to get whose review will be removed.
approved.title: Approved

changes_requested.description: If set to `true`, all the reviews requesting changes will be removed when the pull request is updated. If set to false, nothing will be done. If set to a list, each item should be the GitHub login of a user whose review will be removed. If set to `from_requested_reviewers`, the list of requested reviewers will be used to get whose review will be removed.
changes_requested.title: Changes Requested

message.description: Message to use when dismissing reviews.
message.title: Message

when.description: If set to `synchronize`, the action will run only if the pull request commits changed. Otherwise, it will run each time the rule matches.
when.title: When

draft.description: If the pull request should be a draft (true) or the other way around (false).
draft.title: Draft

workflow.description: The name of the .yaml GitHub Workflow file with its extension.
workflow.title: Workflow

ref.description: The reference to use when triggering the job. If none is passed, the default repository branch is used.
ref.title: Ref

inputs.description: The inputs passed to your workflow execution if any. Values can be either a template, a number or a Boolean.
inputs.title: Inputs

dispatch.description: The list of workflows to dispatch via the action.
dispatch.title: Dispatch

LabelActionModel.description: Add or remove labels on a pull request.

add.description: The list of labels to add.
add.title: Add

remove.description: The list of labels to remove.
remove.title: Remove

remove_all.description: Remove all labels from the pull request.
remove_all.title: Remove All

toggle.description: Toggle labels in the list based on the conditions. If all the conditions are a success, all the labels in the list will be added, otherwise, they will all be removed.
toggle.title: Toggle

LabelActionModel.title: LabelActionModel

method.description: Merge method to use. If no value is set, Mergify uses the first authorized method available in the repository configuration.
method.title: Method

merge_bot_account.description: Mergify can impersonate a GitHub user to merge pull requests. If no `merge_bot_account` is set, Mergify merges the pull request itself. The user account **must** have already been logged in Mergify dashboard once and have **write** or **maintain** permission.
merge_bot_account.title: Merge Bot Account

commit_message_template.description: Template to use as the commit message when using the merge or squash merge method.
commit_message_template.title: Commit Message Template

allow_merging_configuration_change.description: Allow merging the Mergify configuration file. *This option does not do anything and is only present for backward compatibility.*
allow_merging_configuration_change.title: Allow Merging Configuration Change

max_parallel_checks.description: The maximum number of speculative checks allowed to run at the same time.
max_parallel_checks.title: Max Parallel Checks

title.default: '{{ check_rule_name }}'{% if check_status == 'success' %} succeeded{% elif check_status == 'failure' %} failed{% endif %}
title.title: Title

success_conditions.description: List of conditions to match to mark the pull request check as succeeded, otherwise, it will be marked as failing. If unset, the conditions from the rule that triggers this action are used.

neutral_conditions.description: List of conditions to match to mark the pull request check as neutral, otherwise, it will be marked as failing.

conditions.description: The list of conditions that needs to match to assign priority to the pull request.

priority.description: The priority of the pull request.
priority.title: Priority

allow_checks_interruption.description: Allow interrupting the ongoing checks when the pull request entering the queue has a higher priority than the queued one(s). If set to false, a pull request with higher priority will be inserted just after the pull requests that have checks running.
allow_checks_interruption.title: Allow Checks Interruption

name.description: The name of the rule. This is used when reporting information about a rule. It's not possible to have two rules with the same name.
name.title: Name

disabled.description: If the rule is disabled, the reason why it's disabled.

conditions.description: The conditions that must be met for the rule to be evaluated.

actions.description: The actions to perform when the rule matches.

name.description: The name of the queue where the pull request should be added. If no name is set, queue_conditions will be applied instead.
name.title: Name

configuration_deprecated_attribute.deprecated_summary_ghes_mode:
:bangbang: **Action Required** :bangbang:
> **The configuration uses the deprecated `merge_method` attribute of the queue action in one or more `pull_request_rules`. It must now be used under the `queue_rules` configuration.**
> This option will be removed in a future version.
> For more information: https://docs.mergify.com/configuration/file-format/#queue-rules
configuration_deprecated_attribute.deprecated_summary_saas_mode:
:bangbang: **Action Required** :bangbang:
> **The configuration uses the deprecated `merge_method` attribute of the queue action in one or more `pull_request_rules`. It must now be used under the `queue_rules` configuration.**
> A brownout is planned on September 16th, 2024.
> This option will be removed on October 21st, 2024.
> For more information: https://docs.mergify.com/configuration/file-format/#queue-rules

merge_method.description: Merge method to use. If no value is set, Mergify uses the first authorized method available in the repository configuration.
merge_method.title: Merge Method

merge_bot_account.description: Mergify can impersonate a GitHub user to merge pull requests. If no `merge_bot_account` is set, Mergify merges the pull request itself. The user account **must** have already been logged in Mergify dashboard once and have **write** or **maintain** permission.
merge_bot_account.title: Merge Bot Account

configuration_deprecated_attribute.deprecated_summary_saas_mode:
:bangbang: **Action Required** :bangbang:

update_bot_account.description: For certain actions, such as rebasing branches, Mergify has to impersonate a GitHub user. You can specify the account to use with this option. If no `update_bot_account` is set, Mergify picks randomly one of the organization users instead. The user account **must** have already been logged in Mergify dashboard once. This option overrides the value defined in the queue rules section of the configuration.
update_bot_account.title: Update Bot Account

configuration_deprecated_attribute.deprecated_summary_ghes_mode:
:bangbang: **Action Required** :bangbang:
> **The configuration uses the deprecated `update_method` attribute of the queue action in one or more `pull_request_rules`. It must now be used under the `queue_rules` configuration.**
> This option will be removed in a future version.
> For more information: https://docs.mergify.com/configuration/file-format/#queue-rules
configuration_deprecated_attribute.deprecated_summary_saas_mode:
:bangbang: **Action Required** :bangbang:
> **The configuration uses the deprecated `update_method` attribute of the queue action in one or more `pull_request_rules`. It must now be used under the `queue_rules` configuration.**
> A brownout is planned on September 16th, 2024.
> This option will be removed on October 21st, 2024.
> For more information: https://docs.mergify.com/configuration/file-format/#queue-rules

update_method.description:
Method to use to update the pull request with its base
branch when the speculative check is done in place. Possible values:

- `merge` to merge the base branch into the pull request.
- `rebase` to rebase the pull request against its base branch.

This option overrides the value defined in the queue rules section of the configuration.
The default is rebase when the `merge_method` is `fast-forward`.
update_method.title: Update Method

allow_merging_configuration_change.description: Allow merging the Mergify configuration file. *This option does not do anything and is only present for backward compatibility.*
allow_merging_configuration_change.title: Allow Merging Configuration Change

autosquash.description: This option is relevant only if you do in place checks and if you use the `rebase` option of the update_method. It will automatically squash your commits beginning by `squash!`, `fixup!` or `amend!`, just like the option with the same name when doing a `git rebase`.
autosquash.title: Autosquash

configuration_deprecated_attribute.deprecated_summary_ghes_mode:
:bangbang: **Action Required** :bangbang:

> This option will be removed in a future version.
> For more information: https://docs.mergify.com/configuration/file-format/#priority-rules

bot_account.description: To rebase, Mergify needs to impersonate a GitHub user. You can specify the account to use with this option. If no `bot_account` is set, Mergify picks the pull request author. The user account must have already been logged in Mergify dashboard once.
bot_account.title: Bot Account

autosquash.description: When set to `true`, commits starting with `fixup!`, `squash!` and `amend!` are squashed during the rebase.
autosquash.title: Autosquash

bot_account.description: Mergify can impersonate a GitHub user to request a review on a pull request. If no `bot_account` is set, Mergify will request the review itself.
bot_account.title: Bot Account

random_count.description: Pick random users and teams from the provided lists. When `random_count` is specified, `users` and `teams` can be a dictionary where the key is the login and the value is the weight to use. Weight must be between 1 and 15 included.
random_count.title: Random Count

users.description: The usernames to request reviews from.
users.title: Users

teams.description: The team names to request reviews from.
teams.title: Teams

users_from_teams.description: The team names to get the list of users to request reviews from.
users_from_teams.title: Users From Teams

type.description: The type of review to post
type.title: Type

message.description: The message to post in the review
message.title: Message

bot_account.description: Mergify can impersonate a GitHub user to review a pull request. If no `bot_account` is set, Mergify will review the pull request itself.
bot_account.title: Bot Account

RuleConditionModel.description: Model defining a single rule condition 'leaf of a condition tree'
RuleConditionModel.title: RuleConditionModel

bot_account.description: Mergify can impersonate a GitHub user to squash a pull request. If no `bot_account` is set, Mergify will squash the pull request itself
bot_account.title: Bot Account

commit_message.description:
Defines what commit message to use for the squashed commit if no commit message is defined in the pull request body.
Possible values are:

- `all-commits` to use the same format as GitHub squashed merge commit.
- `first-commit` to use the message of the first commit of the pull request.
- `title+body` means to use the title and body from the pull request itself as the commit message. The pull request number will be added to end of the title.
commit_message.title: Commit Message

Template.description: A string template using the Jinja2 syntax.
Template.title: Template

bot_account.description: Mergify can impersonate a GitHub user to update a pull request. If no `bot_account` is set, Mergify will update the pull request itself.
bot_account.title: Bot Account
